We've received several questions about our Xplore enrichment centers for K-6 students at 34 elementary schools. Here are some fast facts:

*While time will be allotted to allow children to participate in remote learning, it may not align with every classroom teacher's schedule.
*No field trips but special activities will rotate to each group.
*Each group of children will have its own materials to the degree possible.
*Hourly cleaning of high-touch surfaces.
*Fee assistance and employee discounts are available.

Learn more and enroll at mpsaz.org/xplore.

Did you know that on the first Arbor Day in 1872, approximately one million trees were planted in Nebraska? Let's see how many Mesa can plant today!

We've just wrapped up another successful day of serving pick-up and drive-through meals to children in our community. We want to take the opportunity to thank all of our dedicated staff who have made this happen. There are many employees working behind the scenes to ensure we best serve our community during this unprecedented time.

Several community members have reached out asking how they can help. Please know that we are keeping this in mind as we plan for the future. At this time, however, only our food & nutrition staff may serve meals, due to the food handler's card requirement by law.

Until we have more opportunities available to share, we encourage you to reach out to friends, families and neighbors to see how you can help. Perhaps it's an elderly neighbor who needs assistance with grocery shopping or families who could use food or other essential donations. However, safety should be your top priority, so please practice social distancing, wash your hands frequently and stay home if sick.

Thank you for your continued support.

post_text: Westwood High teacher Nelsene Alford received an incredible surprise this morning after her special act of bravery. City of Mesa Fire Chief Mary Cameli and Vice Mayor Mark Freeman showed up to Nelsene's classroom to present her with a certificate of appreciation, after saving a person's life using an AED kit. When an individual collapsed while umpiring at a baseball game, Nelsene located the AED kit at the field and delivered two electrical shocks to the individual before emergency responders arrived, saving the person's life. Teachers often act as heroes in our lives and Nelsene is no exception to that. Thank you, Nelsene, for your quick-thinking courage and thank you Chief Cameli, Mesa Fire and Medical Department and Vice Mayor Mark Freeman for celebrating this special member of our community. ❤️

post_text: Congratulations to Skyline High School for winning the Battle of the Belts seatbelt challenge, sponsored by Phoenix Children's Hospital and Valley Toyota Dealers. Students from Dobson, Red Mountain and Skyline High schools participated in the competition, which aims to increase seat belt usage among young drivers and decrease motor vehicle injuries and fatalities. During the competition, schools received three unannounced parking lot audits during the semester to measure seat belt usage, while student organizations conducted educational seatbelt safety campaigns. Skyline's Key Club earned first place in the competition for increasing their school's seat belt usage by 19 percent and received $1,000 and a pizza party from Toyota. Red Mountain earned second place and a $500 prize, and Dobson received $250 for third place. Amazing work, everyone!

This month we are celebrating the incredible achievements and contributions of African-Americans throughout our district's history. In 1921, Veora E. Johnson began her teaching career at Booker T. Johnson Elementary School opened in her honor. Make sure you're following us here and on Instagram and Twitter (@mpsaz) to join us in celebrating more influential members of our community this month.

Five district high schools participated in Hacktivate Mesa this week, a two-day event dedicated to brainstorming solutions to community issues via data analysis. Students were organized into teams of 5-6 and tasked with using data and statistics to solve some of Mesa's biggest community issues including homelessness, opioid abuse, suicide prevention, recycling, parking and transportation and attracting millennials to Mesa's workforce. Prizes for best presentation, most innovative idea and best overall data analysis all went to teams from Red Mountain High School and included drones, floating speakers and VR headsets.
